qas.question: Who is responsible for ensuring the Parliament works smoothly?
Who sets the work agenda and allocates time in the chamber?
How many seats must a political party have to be represented on the Parliamentary Bureau?
Who represents the Scottish Parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity?
Which group sets the time agenda?
Who is not responsible for ensuring Parliament runs smoothly?
Who disagrees with the timetable of business in the chamber?
Which officer represents the Scottish Police Force at home and abroad?

context: As a member of the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body, <a0_2><b5_0>the <a0_0><a0_1>Presiding Officer<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> is responsible for ensuring that the Parliament functions effectively and has the staff, property and resources it requires to operate. Convening <a1_0><a1_2>the <b4_0><b6_0>Parliamentary Bureau<b6_0/><b4_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/>, which allocates time and sets the work agenda in the chamber, is another of the roles of the <a1_1>Presiding Officer<a1_1/>. Under the Standing Orders of the Parliament the Bureau consists of the Presiding Officer and one representative from each political parties with <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>five<a2_0/> or more<a2_1/> seats<a2_2/> in the Parliament. Amongst the duties of the Bureau are to agree the timetable of business in the chamber, establish the number, remit and membership of parliamentary committees and regulate the passage of legislation (bills) through the Parliament. <a3_0><a3_2>The <a3_1><b7_0>Presiding<b7_0/> Officer<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> also represents the Scottish Parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity.
